divs: sighting detailson the evening of july 4, 2009, my fianc��� and i took our children to a carnival in lancaster (near buffalo), new york. as it started to get dark, we positioned ourselves on a patch grass on the corner of broadway and a small side street called "pac way", so we could watch fireworks. we were facing cayuga creek toward aurora street. our youngest son needed to use the bathroom, so my fianc��� left with him to go to the port-a-potties. while they were gone, at approximately 10:00 p.m., a glittery, white firework shot up into the air to the left of the town's water tower, turning my attention to the west. i then noticed a fiery, orange globe rising slowly over the creek to the immediate left of the white firework. i expected the globe to explode into thousands of sparklers, but as the real fireworks display got under way a full 90��� to my right, i realized this fiery globe was not a firework at all. the globe rose gently, floating overhead, gradually ascending and moving at a steady pace to the southeast. my fianc��� returned with our son, and i pointed out the globe to him, which he had also noticed while waiting in line for the bathroom. i had my 35mm camera with me, and my fianc��� asked me to take a picture of the object. but my camera (set to auto focus) struggled to find a focal point in the night sky and would not take the picture. the globe kept ascending and moving farther away until it was no longer visible. i was disappointed, but then we noticed a second fireball rising from the same point of origin as the first, behind the creek. and this time, i was able to capture a photograph with my camera on manual focus. the second globe behaved the same as the first, following the same southeasterly course and gradually getting higher and farther away in the sky to the point of no longer being visible. several spectators who had gathered to watch fireworks were distracted by the globes in the sky, all shouting out speculations as to what the objects could logically be. the consensus seemed to be that they were hot air balloons. i personally find it peculiar (not to mention extremely dangerous) to set off on a hot air balloon joy ride at 10:00 p.m. in such close proximity of a fireworks display. the globes were totally self-contained with nothing attached, hanging or dangling from them, and they ascended to such heights they were no longer visible - clearly higher than hot air balloons would be capable of traveling. while the center of the globes appeared bright orange-red and flickering as if on fire, i am doubtful the globes were any type of flare, as a flare would eventually fall downward. these objects continued to rise higher and higher, drifting off into the night sky. they also did not burn up but maintained their size and perfectly circular shape. after the globes disappeared, we turned our attention back to the fireworks, and, when they were done, packed up for home. we thought we had witnessed a rather odd - but innocuous - event until we noticed several reports of similar experiences cropping up on the internet. we, therefore, felt we should share our own 4th of july \ fire globe event as well.
Summary: Two orange, fiery globes near fireworks.
